sen.j: 衣通姫（そとおりひめ、そとおし－）は、記紀に絶世の美女と伝承される人物。
sen.e: Sotorihime (or Sotooshihime) is a woman described as exquisitely beautiful in "Kojiki" (Record of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.e: Sotoorihime (or Sotooshihime) is a woman described as exquisitely beautiful in the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 大変に美しい女性であったため、その美しさが衣を通して輝くことからこの名がある。
sen.e: Since she was a very beautiful woman, her name had a meaning that her beauty could beam through her clothes.

sen.e: She is also said to have been one of the Honcho Sanbijin (the three beautiful women of Imperial Reigns)

sen.j: 記紀の間で衣通姫の設定が異なる。
sen.e: Stories recorded about her are different between Kojiki and Nihonshoki.

sen.j: 『古事記』には、允恭天皇皇女の軽大娘皇女（かるのおおいらつめ）の別名とし、同母兄である木梨軽皇子（かるのひつぎのみこ）と情を通じるタブーを犯す。
sen.e: According to Kojiki, "Sotoorihime" was another name of Karuno oiratsume who was a princess of Emperor Ingyo, and she broke a taboo by having an affair with Karuno hitsuginomiko who was her elder brother-uterine.

According to the "Kojiki," "Sotoorihime" was another name of Karu no oiratsume who was a princess of Emperor Ingyo, and she broke a taboo by having an affair with Karu no hitsugi no miko who was her older brother-uterine.
sen.cmt: 原文表記に合わせKojiki→the "Kojiki"に修正、Karu no oiratsume、Karu no hitsugi no miko、older brother-uterineとしました。
sen.e: According to the "Kojiki," "Sotoorihime" was another name of Karu no oiratsume who was a princess of Emperor Ingyo, and she broke a taboo by having an affair with Karu no hitsugi no miko who was her older brother-uterine.

sen.j: それが原因で允恭天皇崩御後、軽太子は群臣に背かれて失脚、伊予国へ流刑となるが、衣通姫もそれを追って伊予に赴き、再会を果たした二人は心中する（衣通姫伝説）。
sen.e: As a result, rebelled against by many of his retainers, Karuno hitsuginomiko was overthrown after the demise of Emperor Ingyo and was deported to Iyo Province, where Sotoorihime followed him and the two committed joint suicide (Sotoorihime legend).

As a result, rebelled against by many of his retainers, Karu no hitsugi no miko was overthrown after the demise of Emperor Ingyo and was deported to Iyo Province, where Sotoorihime followed him and the two committed joint suicide (Sotoorihime legend).
sen.cmt: Karu no hitsugi no mikoとしました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』においては、允恭天皇の皇后忍坂大中姫（おしさかのおおなかつのひめ）の妹・弟姫（おとひめ）とされ、允恭天皇に寵愛された妃として描かれる。
sen.e: According to Nihonshoki, she was a younger sister of Emperor Ingyo's empress Oshisakano onakatsunohime and was called Otohime (youngest princess) and also, she is described as having been a princess in favor with Emperor Ingyo.

According to the "Nihonshoki," she was a younger sister of Emperor Ingyo's empress Oshisaka no onakatsunohime and was called Otohime (youngest princess) and also, she is described as having been a princess in favor with Emperor Ingyo.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせ、Nihonshoki→the "Nihonshoki"とし、余分なスペース消去、Oshisaka no onakatsunohimeとしました。

sen.j: 近江国坂田から迎えられ入内し、藤原宮（奈良県橿原市）に住んだ。
sen.e: She, originally living in Sakata, Omi Province, was invited to enter into the imperial court and moved to live in Fujiwara Palace (Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: She, originally living in Sakata, Omi Province, was invited to enter into the imperial court and moved to live in Fujiwara no miya Palace (Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).
sen.cmt: Fujiwara Palace→Fujiwara no miya Palaceとしました。
sen.e: She, originally living in Sakata, Omi Province, was invited to enter into the imperial court and moved to live in Fujiwara no miya Palace (Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: しかし、皇后の嫉妬を理由に河内の茅渟宮（ちぬのみや、大阪府泉佐野市）へ移り住み、天皇は遊猟にかこつけて衣通郎姫の許に通い続ける。
sen.e: But because of Empress's jealousy, Sotoorihime had to move to Chinu no miya in Kawachi Province (Izumisano City, Osaka Prefecture), where Emperor continued to visit her under the pretext of going hunting.

sen.j: 皇后がこれを諌め諭すと、以後の行幸は稀になったという。
sen.e: After Empress remonstrated Emperor about this and dissuaded him from visiting her, his visit to Sotoorihime became rare.

sen.j: 紀伊の国で信仰されていた玉津島姫と同一視され、和歌三神の一柱であるとされる。
sen.e: Identified with Tamatsushima no hime who was enshrined in Kii Province, Sotoorihime is regarded as one of waka sanjin (the Three gods of waka poem).
